Award.AwardTitle: Extrapolating the Concept of Protein Corona for Understanding Nanoparticles at Large

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

#1232724
Ke, Pu-Chun

The scientific community has recently determined that the physical and physicochemical properties of nanoparticles (NPs) deemed so desirable in terms of application are often the direct causes for their complex behavior in the environment. Upon entering the environment through air, water and soil, and during the lifecycle of manufacturing, transport, use and disposal, NPs "at large" undergo constant transformations from their interactions with light, natural organic matter (NOM), microorganisms, and plants. The goal of this proposal is therefore to elucidate the mutable behavior and fate of discharged NPs by extrapolating the established concept of protein "corona", i.e., surface modification of NPs by plasma proteins in the bloodstream, to "biocorona" in the environment. The notion of biocorona encompasses NOM, proteins and carbohydrates that are ubiquitous building blocks of nature. This proposed treatment is validated in that a) biological systems are an essential and integral part of ecosystems, and b) it is the transformed rather than the pristine material, that must be evaluated for potential environmental impact.

Intellectual Merit: Technically, the introduction of biocorona exploits the established experimental, theoretical and computational approaches developed for the research areas of protein adsorption and folding while integrating the elements pertaining to nanotechnology and environmental systems. The three specific aims of this proposal are to elucidate a) NP-biocoronas in the natural aqueous environment, b) NP-biocoronas in plants, and c) biotransformation and degradation of NP-biocoronas by aquatic organisms. The parameter space to be mapped includes solvent hardness and pH, NP size and solubility, protein conformation and binding thermodynamics, plant cell translocation, transport and phytotoxicity, ROS production, and photosynthesis. Results from these studies will offer essential information on the stability and transformation of NPs in the natural aqueous environment, facilitate our understanding of the uptake, biodistribution and toxicity of NPs in plant species, and provide key indicators for evaluating aquatic response to NP exposure.

Broader Impacts: Recent literature on the environmental health and safety of nanotechnology (NanoEHS) has expanded exponentially. Much NanoEHS study is now converging from phenomenological observation and mass testing toward amassing a knowledge base of increasing efficiency and prediction power. To keep pace with the vast variety and growing application of nanomaterials and to accommodate the vast complexity of the environment, methodical approaches such as extrapolated concept of biocorona are logical and cost-effective solutions to environmental risk assessment of nanotechnology. In addition to promoting interdisciplinary research and education at Clemson and Wake Forest University in the Carolinas, funding of this proposal will catalyze fusion of the protein folding community with the community of NanoEHS for cutting-edge innovation with potential economical gains. Furthermore, this proposed frontier research will necessarily foster exchanges between the PIs' labs and their collaborators at Delaware State, Denison, Duke, and Rice Universities, and the National Institute of Chemical Physics and Biophysics in Estonia.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the project was to understand the transformation of nanoparticles (NPs) in the environmental and biological media due to inter-molecular interactions by extending the concept of NP-protein “corona”. We have combined computational modeling with experimental characterization to uncover the structure and dynamics of the molecular complexes between NPs and various environmental and biological molecules. Our research aims to establish a connection between the physicochemical properties of the biocorona constituents and their stability and transformation in biological and natural environment, which will enable our prediction of the function and fate of nanomaterials in the Environmental Health system.

 

During the funding period, we have investigated a range of biologically and environmentally important NPs, including silver nanoparticles (AgNP), dendritic polymer NP, fullerene, fullerenol, carbon nanotubes (CNT), graphene and graphene oxide We studies their interactions with various environmentally and biologically relevant molecules ranging from natural organic matters (NOMs), small molecule ligands, and proteins. The major scientific findings include charactering the structure and dynamics of AgNP-protein corona at the atomic and molecular level; uncovering the physical principles governing the self-assembly of ligands on NP surface; determining the effects of NP surface chemistry on protein binding and subsequent protein conformation changes upon binding; and exploring the effects of NPs on protein misfolding and aggregation. Based on molecular insights obtained from our previous studies and using the combined computational and experimental approaches, we have recently discovered that graphene oxide and OH-terminated PAMAM dendrimers can inhibit the formation of toxic amyloid aggregates of amylin, a peptide hormone whose aggregation is implicated in type-2 diabetes. Within three and a half years of this NSF support, our collaborative team has published 24 peer-reviewed research articles, 3 book chapters and 18 conference proceedings. We expect that the developed approaches will be broadly applicable to the study of Nano-Bio interface. The obtained scientific knowledge will facilitate the development of strategies for environmental remediation against the potentially adverse effects of NPs, benefit our design of environmentally compatible and biologically responsible NPs and devices, and enable the vast applications of nanomedicine.

 

This project has also provided excellent research training and scientific education opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students. Working on the research project has allowed the students to learn both experimental characterization techniques and state-of-the-art multiscale molecular dynamics simulation methods. With the support, three undergraduate students, one Master student, and four PhD students have already successfully defended their theses for the corresponding degrees. Most of them went on in the STEM research field. In addition, this project also allowed the PI and co-PI labs to establish fruitful collaborations domestically and internationally (such as research groups in Australia, Estonia, and Finland).

 


Last Modified: 04/28/2016
Modified by: Feng Ding
